tabs.header_iregular:
Constipation can be painful, let's see what to use over-the-counter.

Over the counter medications or measures that can help with constipation are listed below.

Go through them. You will then answer a few questions to see which will work best for your situation.

If still not satisfied, there is a comparison table at the end of the questions to further tailor the recommendation to your needs.
fieldset: At the tingling or prodrome stage
Small blisters grew together to form a large blister.
Sore is red, raised a little.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

If you think you have a flu:

Please go back and choose the symptom(s) that you feel closely relate to what you have or might have had and let's recommend something for you.

Remember, there is no cure for the flu. All we can do is manage the symptoms if you have one.
mode.2: Something to prevent or boost your resistance to the flu?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have the flu really bad.

Discuss further?
mode.4: You will need an antihistamine.
mode.5: Selection require a decongestant.
mode.6: Selection require a pain / fever reducer.
mode.7: Need an expectorant with or a cough suppressant.
mode.8: Need to quiet down the stomach.
mode.9: Need a decongestant and pain / fever medication based on your selection.
mode.10: Symptoms require an antihistamine and a pain / fever reliever.
mode.11: Selection require an expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever reducer.

mode.17: A decongestant and stomach relief medications are required.

mode.20: Need an antihistamine, expectorant with or cough suppressant and a pain / fever reducer.
mode.21: Selection require an antihistamine, stomach relief and pain / fever reducer.
mode.22: Need a pain / fever reducer, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant relief.
mode.23: Selection require a decongestant, stomach and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.24: Need a pain / fever, stomach and expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.25: Symptoms require a decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and stomach relief medications.
mode.26: Will need an antihistamine, expectorant with or cough suppressant and stomach relief medications.
mode.27: Will need an antihistamine, decongestant and an expectorant / cough suppressant medicatons.
mode.28: Selection require an antihistamine, decongestant and stomach relief medications.
mode.29: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, pain / fever and stomach relief medications.
mode.30: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.31: Need an antihistamine, stomach relief, Pain / fever with expectorant / cough suppressant medications.
mode.32: Symptoms require a decongestant, stomach, pain / fever and expectorant with or cough suppressant relief medications.
mode.33: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, stomach an expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.34:
Okay.
You must have this flu pretty bad.

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 01:50:pm
mode_not.content2: You can compare over the counter multi-symptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Stool softeners click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This allows more water and fat to get into the stool making it softer and easier to move along.

They are stimulant free and generally regarded as gentle.

But expect action in about 1 to 3 days.

Docusate is a good example.

collapsable.title: Bulk-forming fibers click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These cause the stool to retain more water, bulk it up and form something like a gel making it easier to move along.

They are gentle and as such can be used daily to keep things moving.

Some of these fibers are sources of soluble and insoluble fibers. While the insoluble fibers help make things move in the intestine, the soluble fibers have been shown to reduce cholesterol and ultimately heart disease.

In 1998, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorized the use of a health claim that ...diets low in saturated fat and cholesterol that include 7 grams of soluble fiber per day from psyllium may reduce the risk of heart disease by lowering cholesterol... in the labeling of foods and dietary supplements containing psyllium husk.     

If you have a history of constipation, you should include this in your daily routine.       

Examples include:  Psyllium, cellulose, methylcellulose, carboxymethylcellulose sodium, karaya, malt soup extract, polycarbophil, and wheat bran.

collapsable.title: Stimulants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These stimulates or make the intestine more active thereby causing a bowel movement.

They act on the walls and nerves of the intestine, altering the electrolytes and water movement.

They are the most powerful among laxatives, but also the most dangerous.

For instance, prolonged use can damage the ability of the folds in the colon to move stool along on its own because you've over stimulated it.

Then you will need to take another stimulant laxative to move things along and before you know it, you will end up with chronic constipation that is dependent on you having to take these laxatives before you can go. In other words, you will become dependent on them.

So use these on a short term basis. Never more than a week.

Examples are senna extracts, castor oil, bisacodyl, cascara, aloe vera, buckthorn.

collapsable.title: Lubricants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
The idea is to make the stool slippery so it can pass out easily.

A good example is mineral oil. 

Being an oil, mineral oil, also add more water to the stool making it softer, because it prevents the colon from absorbing water.

Only problem is that it will also prevent the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins and some minerals by dissolving them in the oil and passing them out.

collapsable.title: Saline laxatives click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These draws water into the intestine and retain it to make stool softer and more comfortable to pass.

You should take this with a full glass of water not only to make it more effective, but  also prevent side effects like dehydration or electrolyte imbalance.

Examples include magnesium citrate, magnesium hydroxide or milk of magnesia, magnesium sulfate and sodium phosphate.

Stay away from oral sodium phosphates. These when taken at high doses  in some individuals carry a risk of kidney injury. For this reason Fleet phospho-soda  (Oral form. Not enema)  was recalled by the manufacturer.

collapsable.title: Hyper-osmotic agents click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These cause the intestine to hold more water within thereby soften the stool for easy passage.

Their goal is to hydrate the stool, soften it and make it easier to pass.

Examples include glycerin suppository, polyethylene glycol (PEG), sorbitol, lactulose.

irregular.content:
Last updated by pharmacist on : 09/13/2014

You will use this information to choose a good over-the -counter remedy.

Remember to compare the different types of over-the-counter laxatives for a more informed decision using our comparison tool.

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to collapse contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's get this diarrhea under control using OTC measures.

Diarrhea is a symptom. It is always much better to take care of the underlying cause if possible.

Well, for now, you will see what is available over-the-counter to manage diarrhea, answer a few questions to see what will work best and get this under control.

Let's take a look at what is available over the counter for diarrhea management below to start with.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over the counter for this.

This will assume you are combining lifestyle and dietary changes with over-the-counter measures to tackle this heartburn issue if it is an existing problem.

Over-the-counter medications to treat heartburn are generally classified into 3 categories listed below.

You will use information about these 3 categories to choose what will work best for you.

Let's figure this out.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose your symptoms from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: Burning pain. Feels like food is trying to come back into the throat.
I need something for immediate relief.
I have used omeprazole or other PPIs for 2 weeks or more recently.
Feels like food is stuck in the throat when I swallow.
Stool is black like tar or maroon colored.
Did some sit-ups. Now my chest is feeling this burning sensation.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

collapsable.title: Antacids click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Antacids contain alkaline ions (bicarbonate, carbonate or hydroxide) and counterions (Calcium, Magnesium, Sodium, Aluminum) that help to neutralise stomach acids. You should start getting relief in about 30 mins.

The liquid formulation work faster. But the tablets are better for taking along because you may have to take this frequently until you get relief.

Be sure to compare OTC antacids using our comparison tool. For instance some you shouldn't take if you have diarrhea and some if you have constipation.

collapsable.title: H2 blockers click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These reduce acid production in the stomach by blocking the H2 receptors in the stomach. They are not as effective as Proton pump inhibitors but are a good alternative if cost is a problem.

Know that these are used to suppress stomach acid. Don't expect them to work right away if you already have heartburn. They are much better for prevention. If you already have this heartburn, you will have to include an antacid to neutralize the acid already present for fast relief and then use this to prevent further acid production.

Cimetidine, Famotidine, Ranitidine, and nizatidine are examples.

collapsable.title: Antigas click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Simethicone is the main ingredient that dissolves the gas in cases of bloating.

This is an anti-foaming agent that combines tiny air bubbles in the stomach into a bigger one that you can then belch out or pass as gas.

You would use this if you are experiencing bloating along with a heartburn. Some heartburn medications combine this with antacids. This combination is usually preferred.

collapsable.title: Proton Pump Inhibitors click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Omeprazole, Lansoprazole, Esomeprazole. These are used to suppress acid production in the stomach.

The FDA recommends not more than three 14-day treatment courses to be used in one year. This should be sufficient for you. By that I mean, do it 14 days at a time and if you add good dietary habits and other lifestyle changes, you should not need it for more than 3 times in one year.

This is how these drugs work. They irreversibly inhibit the pump that produces acid in the stomach called proton pump. They can knock out up to 99% of these pumps irreversibly which means they will never come back. A 14-day treatment should make this happen. But the stomach will form new pumps to replace the ones that were knocked out which will gradually take a while (average 2 to 3 months) to reach the levels that were causing heartburn before. So if you add good dietary and lifestyle changes to your treatment plan, you should not have to be taking these medications every day just for heartburn relief.

Which should you choose? Well, you will have to use the comparison feature of this app to help you with that.

collapsable.title: Lifestyle changes click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to work on these:

  • Carbonated drinks
  • Alcohol
  • Coffee
  • Caffeinated energy drinks
  • Chocolate, mints or peppermints
  • Citrus fruits
  • Fatty or spicy foods
  • Tomato products
  • Smoking
  • Taking ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

Take these seriously. You may want to make a list and place it on the refrigerator as a reminder.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to work on these:

  • Carbonated drinks
  • Alcohol
  • Coffee
  • Caffeinated energy drinks
  • Chocolate, mints or peppermints
  • Citrus fruits
  • Fatty or spicy foods
  • Tomato products
  • Smoking
  • Taking ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

Take these seriously. You may want to make a list and place it on the refrigerator as a reminder.

collapsable.title: Antacid click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will use this to neutralize the stomach acid already present. This should give you relief within the next 30 mins.

Use the comparison feature of this app to choose a good one that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Antigas click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Antigas click to expand contents

collapsable.title: H2 Blocker click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will want to take this to reduce the production of stomach acid.

Know that it reduces the production of the acid and it will take a few days to kick in. So you may need to combine this with an antacid to neutralise the acid that is already present in the stomach.

Compare H2 blockers using the comparison feature of this app to see which will work best for you.

Just a reminder, you should take this OR a proton pump inhibitor and not both at the same time.

collapsable.title: PPI(Proton pump inhibitors) click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will need this to suppress acid production in the stomach. Know that it takes a while to kick in. If you also need something for immediate relief, add an antacid to neutralize the acid that is currently present in the stomach while this will prevent more from being formed. After a couple of days, you can then stop taking the antacid and continue with a proton pump inhibitor.

Be sure to compare the different types using the comparison table of this app to know which to choose between omeprazole, pantoprazole, esomeprazole.

collapsable.title: Seek Urgent Care click to expand contents
collapsable.content: You will have to see a healthcare provider on this one. Over-the-counter or self-care is not going to take care of this. Don't waste your time and money. It will get worse.

collapsable.title: Combination Products click to expand contents
Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to work on these:

  • Carbonated drinks
  • Alcohol
  • Coffee
  • Caffeinated energy drinks
  • Chocolate, mints or peppermints
  • Citrus fruits
  • Fatty or spicy foods
  • Tomato products
  • Smoking
  • Taking ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

Take these seriously. You may want to make a list and place it on the refrigerator as a reminder.

tabs.header_iregular:
Nausea or vomiting? Let's figure out what to do.

If this nausea and or vomiting is not showing signs of going away, the best thing to do is give the primary care doctor a call.

If it is after hours, call the answering service. Most doctors or the doctor on call will call in an anti-nausea medication to the pharmacy without you having to be seen immediately.

They don't want you coming in to throw up all over the place anyway or have you throwing up on the way to the office. If you doctor's office won't do this, then change doctors fast.

Over-the-counter medications for nausea and or vomiting are for either motion sickness related nausea or syrups that are supposed to help with upset stomach.

We will talk about these and ways to prevent dehydration and electrolyte loss. 

With these in mind, see what is recommended below.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose your symptoms from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: At the tingling or prodrome stage
Small blisters grew together to form a large blister.
Sore is red, raised a little.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

If you think you have a flu:

Please go back and choose the symptom(s) that you feel closely relate to what you have or might have had and let's recommend something for you.

Remember, there is no cure for the flu. All we can do is manage the symptoms if you have one.
mode.2: Something to prevent or boost your resistance to the flu?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have the flu really bad.

Discuss further?

mode.27: Will need an antihistamine, decongestant and an expectorant / cough suppressant medicatons.
mode.28: Selection require an antihistamine, decongestant and stomach relief medications.
mode.29: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, pain / fever and stomach relief medications.
mode.30: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.31: Need an antihistamine, stomach relief, Pain / fever with expectorant / cough suppressant medications.
mode.32: Symptoms require a decongestant, stomach, pain / fever and expectorant with or cough suppressant relief medications.
mode.33: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, stomach an expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.34:
Okay.
You must have this flu pretty bad.

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 01:50:pm
mode_not.content2: You can compare over the counter multi-symptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header: No comments or ratings on this recommendation yet. How about being the first to say something?
tabs.why:
• Let others know if the recommendation worked for you.
  • Share your treatment outcome with others.
  • Add to the recommendation.
  • Improve on the recommendation.
  • Quickest way to ask a pharmacist a question.
  • What about you answering a question?
